awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CISE-MSI: RCBP-RF: CPS, CNS: Emergency Response and Evacuation Training for Active Shooter Events
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

In recent years, we have witnessed a sharp increase in active shooter events; however, unfortunately, there has been no introduction of new technology or tactics capable of increasing preparedness and training for active shooter events. This project promotes the progress of science and technology development by building interdisciplinary partnerships and research capacity between Bowie State University (BSU) and University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV) for exploratory investigation of active shooter events at Institutes of Higher Education (IHE). The goal of this project is to conduct data collection, preliminary experiments, and a prototype development for the two campuses for improving emergency preparedness for an active shooter event using collaborative immersive virtual reality (VR) environment. This project develops algorithms, implement software and demonstrate proof-of-concept using building systems as a challenge application area. 

This research involves devising novel conceptual methods for new theoretical and empirical guidance needed to have an environment for human and machine decision making for highly uncertain, complex, time urgent, and dynamically changing missions. The research objectives of this proposal include: 1) Develop an immersive Collaborative Virtual Environment (CVE) using Oculus for course of action, visualization, and situational awareness for active shooter events, 2) Develop a unique immersive graphical user interface (GUI) for communicating between PCs (Player characters) and NPCs (Non-Player Characters) for user interaction, 3) Implementing algorithms for human behavior for NPCs in active shooter events. (e.g. Hostile, Non-Hostile, Selfish, Leader-Following, Panic), 4) Deep learning-based (data-driven) behavioral modeling for realistic NPCs. The successfully implemented project contributes to the state-of-the-art in emergency response training using VR by developing knowledge that could form the basis of public education and awareness programs to help facility occupants, their rescuers and city officials respond appropriately during extreme emergency situation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Collaborative Research award: Emergency Response and Evacuation Training for Active Shooter Events facilitated a new partnership between the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV) and the University of North Texas (UNT), involving faculty from Electrical Engineering (Morris, UNLV), Civil Engineering (Park, UNLV), and Data Science (Sharma, UNT). This collaboration integrated expertise in virtual reality (VR) systems, emergency management, and machine learning to address challenges in public safety with a specific focus on mass shootings.

This project made significant contributions to emergency response, public education, and research collaboration by developing advanced simulation tools and strategies for emergency evacuation and active shooter scenarios. The research produced two impactful studies: one focused on creating a lightweight 3D model for mobile platforms and VR to enhance public awareness and education on evacuation procedures, and the other demonstrated the vital role of trained evacuation leaders in significantly reducing fatalities during active shooter events. These findings highlight the importance of integrating trained leadership into emergency response protocols.

A major outcome of this project was the creation of a VR environment tailored for emergency response education and training.  The VR environment was built in with the Unity game engine to handle 3D graphics and VR integration through the Meta Quest 2 goggles.  An accurate model of the UNLV's Science and Engineering Building (SEB) was constructed from floor plans using Google SketchUp and Unity.  Building inhabitants were randomly simulated using the Social Forces model - to model students passing through the ground floor of the building between classes or scientists/researchers traveling between offices and labs on the upper floors. This realistic simulation offers a way to enhance the practical applicability of the VR environment for emergency preparedness training. 

The research findings have direct applications in training, education, and strategy development for high-risk environments such as schools, malls, and other public spaces. Published human behavioral models for computer simulations provide a foundation for future research to develop more realistic and effective simulation scenarios. These insights underscore the importance of integrating technology and human behavioral understanding into emergency response protocols.

Student outcomes include training students in topics of human behavior in emergency situations, focusing on various behaviors observed during evacuations, such as social force model, leader-following, crowd dynamics, and panic.  The behaviors were incorporated into simulation models for more realistic representation of evacuation scenarios.  Students were also engaged in 3D building modeling and programming using various software tools such as Google SketchUp and Unity.  Deepak Yeddula completed his MS in Computer Science with the support of this grant.  

In addition to these technological and educational advancements, the project prioritized collaboration with Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs), enhancing research capacity and providing faculty and students at MSIs with opportunities to engage in cutting-edge research. This initiative strengthened academic partnerships and established a foundation for future large-scale studies on innovative public safety solutions.

The project's outputs include three collaborative publications: a high-ranking journal article and two conference papers, reflecting the scholarly impact of the research. Furthermore, the findings on the role of trained evacuation leaders during active shooter scenarios offer actionable insights for improving emergency response protocols. These contributions have the potential to significantly enhance training programs, public education, and emergency response strategies, ultimately fostering safer environments in public spaces.

  • [J] Arteaga, C., Park, J., Morris, B., Sharma, S., (2023). "Effect of trained evacuation leaders on victims' safety during an active shooter incident." Safety Science, vol. 158, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ssci.2022.105967
  • [C] Sharma, S., Park, J. and Morris, B.T., (2023). "Immersive security personnel training module for active shooter events." Electronic Imaging, 35(12), pp.217-1.
  • [C] Ahmed, N., Park, J., Morris, B., (2022). "Generating a Simplistic 3D Model for Mobile Platform Applications," Proceeding of the 2022 International Conference on Construction Engineering and Project Management, Las Vegas, NV, USA, 20-23 June 2022.
